t: Job 15
Eliphaz Accuses: Job Does Not Fear God
Then*p Eliphaz the Temanite answered and said:
“Should*pn a wise man answer with windy knowledge, and*ld fill his belly with the east wind?
Should*ln he argue in unprofitable talk, or*ld in words with which he can do no good?
But*ln you are doing away with the fear of God and*ld hindering meditation before God.
For*ln your iniquity teaches your mouth, and*ld you choose the tongue of the crafty.
Your*ln own mouth condemns you, and not I; your*ld own lips testify against you.
“Are*pn you the first man who was born? Or*ld were you brought forth before the hills?
Have*ln you listened in the council of God? And*ld do you limit wisdom to yourself?
What*ln do you know that we do not know? What*ld do you understand that is not clear to us?
Both*ln the gray-haired and the aged are among us, older*ld than your father.
Are*ln the comforts of God too small for you, or*ld the word that deals gently with you?
Why*ln does your heart carry you away, and*ld why do your eyes flash,
that*ln you turn your spirit against God and*ld bring such words out of your mouth?
What*ln is man, that he can be pure? Or*ld he who is born of a woman, that he can be righteous?
Behold,*ln God puts no trust in his holy ones, and*ld the heavens are not pure in his sight;
how*ln much less one who is abominable and corrupt, a*ld man who drinks injustice like water!
“I*pn will show you; hear me, and*ld what I have seen I will declare
(what*ln wise men have told, without*ld hiding it from their fathers,
to*ln whom alone the land was given, and*ld no stranger passed among them).
The*ln wicked man writhes in pain all his days, through*ld all the years that are laid up for the ruthless.
Dreadful*ln sounds are in his ears; in*ld prosperity the destroyer will come upon him.
He*ln does not believe that he will return out of darkness, and*ld he is marked for the sword.
He*ln wanders abroad for bread, saying, ‘Where is it?’ He*ld knows that a day of darkness is ready at his hand;
distress*ln and anguish terrify him; they*ld prevail against him, like a king ready for battle.
Because*ln he has stretched out his hand against God and*ld defies the Almighty,
running*ln stubbornly against him with*ld a thickly bossed shield;
because*ln he has covered his face with his fat and*ld gathered fat upon his waist
and*ln has lived in desolate cities, in*ld houses that none should inhabit, which*ld were ready to become heaps of ruins;
he*ln will not be rich, and his wealth will not endure, nor*ld will his possessions spread over the earth;
he*ln will not depart from darkness; the*ld flame will dry up his shoots, and*ld by the breath of his mouth he will depart.
Let*ln him not trust in emptiness, deceiving himself, for*ld emptiness will be his payment.
It*ln will be paid in full before his time, and*ld his branch will not be green.
He*ln will shake off his unripe grape like the vine, and*ld cast off his blossom like the olive tree.
For*ln the company of the godless is barren, and*ld fire consumes the tents of bribery.
They*ln conceive trouble and give birth to evil, and*ld their womb prepares deceit.”
